Denial of Service.description: An attacker can make your authentication system unusable or unavailable.
An attacker can flood our network with junk packets
An attacker can drain upstream resources outside of our control that will prevent access to our applications
An attacker can spend our cloud budget.
An attacker can make a server unavailable or unusable without ever authenticating but the problem goes away when the attacker stops.
An attacker can make a client unavailable or unusable and the problem persists after the attacker goes away.
An attacker can make a server unavailable or unusable and the problem persists after the attacker goes away.
An attacker can make a client unavailable or unusable without ever authenticating and the problem persists after the attacker goes away.
An attacker can make a server unavailable or unusable without ever authenticating and the problem persists after the attacker goes away.
An attacker can cause the logging subsystem to stop working.
An attacker can amplify a Denial of Service attack through this component with amplification on the order of 10 to 1.
An attacker can amplify a Denial of Service attack through this component with amplification on the order of 100 to 1.
An attacker overloads the authentication server with excessive login requests, causing a service slowdown for legitimate users.
A threat actor sends malformed packets to an IoT device, causing it to reboot repeatedly and drain its battery.
An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the application's image processing library to cause a server crash by uploading specially crafted images.
An attacker repeatedly uses an API key reset feature with forged requests, causing excessive consumption of system resources.
A distributed botnet performs a credential stuffing attack on a public-facing API, leading to service degradation.
A hacker disrupts a financial service application by triggering continuous transaction rollbacks through database locking.
An attacker induces a race condition by making concurrent, conflicting configuration changes, causing system instability.
Through DNS amplification, an attacker floods an organization's servers with DNS response traffic, overwhelming network capacity.
An attacker uses session fixation to create thousands of invalid sessions on an e-commerce site, consuming server resources.
Malicious scripts are injected into a web application, causing endless loops that freeze user browsers and exhaust client resources.
